data.text: Planning a Bike Touring Trip Through Balkans/Carpathians

Hi guys Thinking about bike-touring in the Balkans/**Carpathians**, this is just a 1st, rough draft of the route. As you can see, I'm avoiding the Adriatic coast, since it's too busy/touristy. In general, I like/prefer small roads/cycle paths, hills/climbs, remote/quiet places/areas, flexibility/serendipity, slashes üòâ and a combination of camping/B&B's/WarmShovers. Would appreciate your input/recommendations re. route, threats (stray dogs, as I read everywhere, lock your bike every time, etc.), sights, wild camping, ... Thanks! EDIT: 1. Following your great recommendations, I will not skip Albania üôÇ (if I can really make it that far) 1. I use mapy.cz for route planning/navigation
I would cross Albania and not North Macedonia.
data.author: Bert van Sprang

data.text: Thanks. And why, pray tell?
data.author: Jan Brandner

data.text: In North Macedonia we had big roads, many traffic and Ost-European atmosfere. In Albania we had small road, beautifull scenery, Mediteranian atmosfer etcetera.
data.author: Bert van Sprang

data.text: you can see Albanija and Macedonia,if you come from sea, Duresh to Elbasan (Al), then Struga, Ohrid, Bitola (MK). Then go to Greece (Florina.....). Ohrid is the most beautiful city in Macedonia, you Will not mistake. There are not big roads in this region. I'm driving in this area. You can vist Ohrid lake and Prespa lake. Bitola is one of the oldest city in Balkan. With very old an beautiful arhitekture. If you crossing Bitola call meüòâ

data.text: Wooow! That‚Äôs a lot of distance. In Romania try to avoid the main national roads marked with single numbers like 1,2,3‚Ä¶These are usually busy and full of trucks. And being a local I will do things a bit different but i don‚Äôt want to mess your plan. The area around point 8 and west of 13 are very nice. If you need more infos feel free to message me, but before 20.05 because then we leave for our 2.5 weeks trip to Croatia.
data.author: Adrian Niculae

data.text: Oh, and in Bulgaria we liked very much the road from Gabrovo - Shipka pass - Kazanlak - Borilovo - Haskovo - Perpetikon Fort - Kirkovo and passing into Greece at Makaza. Also very nice the road from Asenovgrad to Zlatograd.
data.author: Adrian Niculae

data.text: Thanks, this is just a rough plan. I'm planning the detailed daily routes only 1 or 2 days ahead, based on recommendations from locals. The general idea is to explore the Carpathian Mountains. Have a nice trip in Croatia.
data.author: Jan Brandner

data.text: This is solid advice. In general, rural, hilly Romania is absolutely delightful. In the southern Carpathians, the Iconic Transcarpathian 7C is a must (less busy on weekdays). 73C to Ramnicu Valcea will allow (through a busy stretch to Brezoi) to link up with7A going west and up to Ob√¢r»ôia Lotrului. In general, Take your time to explore the stretches of roads/alternatives with 3 digits whenever possible even if longer, for example east of the aforementioned 7C there are lots of charming such alternatives south of the busy E68. The more digits, the better.
data.author: Stefan Ilcus

Have you heard of or seen this website ? https://cycle.travel/
cycle.travel | route-planner and maps - traffic-free & quiet roads

data.author: Mat Frost

data.text: It is an incredible bike route planning website. It routes you on the quietest roads, and where possible on designated routes, like in the UK the NCN (National Cycle Network) routes.
data.author: Mat Frost

data.text:
I just put in Budapest to Belgrade and this is the route it gave me https://cycle.travel/map?from=Budapest&to=Athens&fromLL=47.48138955,19.14609412691246&toLL=37.9839412,23.7283052
Bike map | Cycle route planner | cycle.travel
cycle.travel
data.author: Mat Frost

data.text: You can literally grab any part of the route with your mouse, and move it around to re-route yourself. It may be worth you looking at it if you are thinking of planning 1 or 2 days ahead. You can keep the whole route and then if a local say go here or there, you can then just move the route if needed
data.author: Mat Frost

data.text: Dont miss Novi Sad near Belgrade if you have time.

data.text: I can see your route is passing through the Romanian Mountains and one word of advice is just be mindfull of the üêª bears . Other than that just the norm i.e lock in bike in towns and use local the curency for any purchases you make .
data.author: Victor Stroe

data.text: OK, Thanks! So not only stray dogs but also bears üòÄ Let's hope the 80's music playing from my speaker on the handlebars will scare them away!
data.author: Jan Brandner

data.text: Will it be enough to just make sure to not surprise them by always making ones presence obvious? (sound) Or does one also need to take further precautions like cook and brush teeth at least 100 meters away from the tent/sleep place, not have smelly food, hang up food in tree, .... Never toured in SE Europe, hopefully will in the future. Have toured in Scandinavia where there are also some hundred bears and the latter precautions are not needed in Scandinavia because they naturally stay away from humans.
data.author: Wulfram Georg Tanner

data.text: Re local currency: In Hungary, you can pay by card everywhere, even in the smallest village, thanks to the illiberal and wise government of Viktor Orban, praise be (ü§™). How is it in Romania?
data.author: Jan Brandner

data.text: The same, you can pay by credit card
data.author: Adrian Cozlea

data.text: I would say shepherd dogs are a bigger problem than stray dogs, and yes, lots of bears too in here. But if you don't use too remote roads (ie: back-country dirt roads through dense forests; lesser/secondary paved roads are still ok) both risks are on acceptable level. But just to be sure have a bear spray on your side (handy against aggressive dogs, too) and try not to wild camp at remote places. Use campings or somewhere closer to human presence.
data.author: Barab√°s Csaba

data.text: Thanks for the tip. I need to learn this phrase in Romanian: I'm afraid of bears, and although I have a bear spray, I don't think it really works, would you please allow me to pitch my tent in your garden, just for 1 night? üòÄ
data.author: Jan Brandner

data.text: The thing in Romania is that due to an ill-advised hunting ban law from a couple of years ago, the bear population exploded in the recent years. They are simply too many compared to the amount of forested area. And naturally the more bears, the bigger the chance that some of them won't behave like normal bears: they get used to human presence, or in some cases get frenzied due to some trauma, etc. So I would say additional precaution is best.
data.author: Barab√°s Csaba

data.text: I start from Denmark and hope to reach Bosnia by July for the Mars Mira (a walk in eastern Bosnia to remember Srebrenica). I plan to ride to Kosovo from Rozaje in Montenegro which is also a very nice border crossing. Then towards Theth in Albania where some of the stretch is on a hiking path I think. Then to Shkod√´r and then towards Prizren in Kosovo via Kukes. That will probably be the most beautiful part of my whole route towards Turkey.

data.text: I don't take into account cars or traffic when I cycle. You will miss some fabulous views if you choose not to cycle the Montenegrin coastline. I rode into Albania from the tip of Montenegro and spent the winter in Tirana. There will be a lot, lot, lot of climbing on this trip. Have fun

data.text: Point 14: A new road, a quiet area, with Djerdap you have a lot to see. You have a stray dog near the neighborhood. By point 15 you have roadworks in some places and part of the bad road. The distance from the cities is as follows: Donji Milanovac - Kladovo about 50km, mostly uphill drive, Kladovo - Negotin about 60 km, good road without big ascents, Negotin - Zajeƒçar about 60 km mostly good road, Zajeƒçar - Knjazevac about 40 km, there are road works Knjazevac - Svrljig around 35 km mostly uphill, with higher ascents, and at the end Svrljig - Ni≈° around 35 km. Anyway no one touches you, nice route.

data.text: In Bulgaria we have lots of stray dogs and wild animals roam during the night and in the small hours. Generally people are hospitable but it is best to lock the bike everywhere. There are lots of places where you can sleep in the wild but not in national parks. Have a nice trip!

data.text: I just rode from Barcelona to Vienna. Slovenia was really nice. Euro zone and Schengen. I found a sweet fresh quiet road south of Ljubljana. Croatia and Hungary a little less so. I wasn't really happy with the traffic in Hungary. I want to fly into Venice and ride to Athens now on a similar route. I like water, so I want to try to hit all of the countries and see the coast.
data.author: Eric Knudstrup

data.text: It's so sad that you're avoiding Albania and Montenegro, however have fun on the road üëç and if you pass by Prishtina/Kosovo visit us at Bike Friendly Caf√© for a free beer üëç
data.author: Arlind Demaj

data.text: We cycled quite a bit through the balkan and cycled last year home to Amsterdam from Montenegro. Albania and Montenegro are just very beautiful and also Bosni√´ Herzegovina. Voivodina in Serbia. As for Croatia, if you take smaller roads it will not be too busy and it also depends on your timing. We cycled in june through the velebit national park to the coast and saw noone (but many dead frogs for some reason). Kotor is indeed touristy but is definitely stunning, and again here, as soon as you go off the beaten track you wil encounter noone. For example Crkvice has a very interesting history. Skhodra lake is very beautiful to cycle at the west side of the lake. Good luck! Below what we cycled last year. And the albanian raw fish is just delicious. In tirana, the restaurant fishop is just amazing. Reservation needed because it is a small local restaurant.
data.author: Marie-Jose Zondag

data.text: Well. Not only the Balkans, the Carpathians too. For example people around point 9, they are part of the Carpathian realm almost completely. It's like saying that Barcelona is an Atlantic city, not Mediterranean. 14 will be a megahiglight, allow time to do it slowly and not on a weekend. 12 - it seems to be the TransAlpina Road. Why not cross the Carpathians 100 km earlier on Transfagarasan. Much more fun. And the road will be open soon, the snow is gone. PS. If you need anything in Romania please PM.

data.text: You are not going to Albania ?? I think you are missing the target. Albania is better than Greece. According to what I am seeing on this map iron legs are needed. North Macedonia is difficult and you can have problem with bears if bivouac into wild nature. The southern part of Greece near kalamata is also very difficult. If you love mountains its OK but if you have low energy level it's gonna be difficult. I recommend you to go Albania instead of north Macedonia.

data.author: Anchica Chobot

data.text:
Where your map shows 27 there is no border crossing between N Macedonia and Kosovo (Restelice). I have been told this just a couple of months ago by knowledgeable people working in the area. If you try and cross you may be arrested, there are police patrols. In any case even if you manage to cross you won't have an entry stamp in your passport which may cause you problems when leaving the country. You must enter N Macedonia at Gllobocica, Debar or Kjafasan - or miss the country out entirely, and go through eastern Albania and enter Greece at Krystallopigi. Where your map shows 28 (I believe this is the Cakor Pass in the Rugova Canyon?) there is also no official border crossing here. However you can get a special permit allowing you to cross into Montenegro or Kosovo at non-official border crossings. At least I hope you can, that's the way I'm planning to cycle myself in September! I recommend you contact zbulo.org who can help arrange the permit for a small fee.
Walking, Hiking, Trekking in Albania, Kosovo and Montenegro with Zbulo! Discover Albania
zbulo.org

data.text: Also in Greece you can pass from Vikos Gorge, Meteora , Valia Kalda , Zagorochoria , Generally pindus mountains are very beautiful. The Peloponnese with the numerous castles , Nafplio a beuatiful city , Leonidio for Climbing , Athens , Volos for tsipouro , Pilio and its majestic villages , Olympus , The old town in Thessaloniki and the castle , Also next to Alexandroupoli is the easily accessible Samothraki island....an amazing hippy island with high mountain and endless waterfalls and natural pools.
data.author: Sotos Dittopoulos

data.text: I did the South coast of Crete and crossed the island from West to East. It was heavy and wonderful. From Gythio or Neapoli on the peleponessos you can take a boat to Kissamos on West Crete. After finishing on the east coast I took the boat from Sitia to Athens, but you can also got to Rhodos from there
